item.text: A thing is an abstract term. In common parlance, it is a general term commonly used to refer to and object. Our conception of this term is heavily influenced by the history of ideas. The modern meaning takes it's lead from the [[Referential Theory of Meaning]]

A thing is an abstract term. In common parlance, it is a general term commonly used to refer to an object. Our conception of this term is heavily influenced by the history of ideas. The modern meaning takes it's lead from the [[Referential Theory of Meaning]].

Interestingly however the original sense of the word "thing" is that of a gathering or political assembly - an early law court. The meaning of a "thing" in this sense is a political definition, and it would seem by looking at the history of legal terminology, we can see how this softer deliberative meaning, became codified.
Witgenstein famously https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Direct_reference_theory

A thing is an abstract term. In common parlance, it is a general term commonly used to refer to an object. Our conception of this term is heavily influenced by the history of ideas. The modern meaning takes it's lead from the referential theory of meaning [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Direct_reference_theory - Wikipedia].

Interestingly however the original sense of the word "thing" is that of a gathering or political assembly. A [[Thingstead was an early law court]]. The meaning of a "thing" in this sense is a political definition, and it would seem by looking at the history of legal terminology, we can see how this softer deliberative meaning, became codified.

A thing is an abstract term. In common parlance, it is a general term we use to refer to an object. Our conception of this term is heavily influenced by the history of ideas. The modern meaning takes it's lead from the [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Direct_reference_theory referential theory of meaning - Wikipedia].

story.text: [[Bruno Latour]] is the philosopher behind the title of this wiki. On this wiki we [[Idea Mine]] a range of disciplines around the notion that science, law, media and politics can be remixed in new and potentially fruitful ways.

A thing is an abstract term. In common parlance, it is a general term we use to refer to an object. The modern meaning takes it's lead from the [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Direct_reference_theory referential theory of meaning - Wikipedia].

Interestingly however the original sense of the word "thing" is that of a gathering or political assembly. A [[Thingstead]] was an early law court. The meaning of a "thing" in this sense is a political definition, and it would seem by looking at the history of legal terminology, we can see how this softer deliberative meaning, became codified.

[[Witgenstein]] famously argued against referentialism, famously saying that "the meaning of a word is its use" - [http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/wittgenstein/#Mea Stanford Encyclopaedia of Philosophy].
A [[Chose in Action]] is a [[Common Law]] legal definition derived form the French meaning [[Thing in Action]].
